SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: While intractable itching may be rarely associated with postherpetic neuralgia, it can have catastrophic complications if present
METHOD: We highlight a severe case of postherpetic itching in a 10-year-old male with Fanconi's and aplastic anemia, refractory to conventional treatments and requiring intravenous sedation
RESULTS: Our use of 3 sequential stellate ganglion blocks with 5.5 mL of 0.25% bupivacaine provided significant improvement of the symptoms for 4 months after the last procedure
CONCLUSION: Although further evaluation is needed, we feel that novel use of sympathetic blockade may provide treatment for intractable itching
Highlighted is the possible influence of the sympathetic system in the pathophysiology of postherpetic itch
IMPLICATION: The use of serial stellate ganglion blocks may be a treatment option for patients with intractable itching and postherpertic neuralgia of the neck and arm region
This technique may lead to more permanent solutions such as pulse radiofrequency lesion or chemical neurolysis of sympathetic ganglions for postherpetic itch
